answer.answer_text: \[\Delta x = \dfrac{b-a}{n},\] de onde concluímos que \(\Delta x \longrightarrow 0\) quando \(n \longrightarrow + \infty\). Assim, independente das escolhas dos pontos amostrais, temos que \[\int_a^b f(x) \, dx = \lim\limits_{n \to + \infty} \sum_{i=1}^n f(x_i^*) \Delta x.\]

answer.answer_text: \(S_n - qS_n = a_1 - a_1q^n\), de onde concluímos que \[S_n = \dfrac{a_1(1 - q^n)}{1-q}.\]

answer.answer_text: \begin{eqnarray*} & & \sum_{i = 1}^n f(x_i^*) \Delta x \\ & & \\ &=& \dfrac{1}{n}\left(e^1 + e^{\small{1 + \frac{1}{n}}} + \cdots + e^{\small{1 + \frac{n-1}{n}}}\right) \\ & & \\ &=& \dfrac{e}{n}\left(1 + e^{\small{\frac{1}{n}}} + \cdots + e^{\small{\frac{n-1}{n}}}\right) \\ & & \\ &=& e(1-e) \left(\dfrac{1/n}{1 - e^{1/n}}\right) \end{eqnarray*}
